instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00164: What is 820-00164? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC: What is PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC? PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC Is a reference voltage for the SMCâ€™s voltage sensors & other sensors..
definitions.SMC_TPAD_RST_L: What is SMC_TPAD_RST_L? SMC_TPAD_RST_L is a signal that comes from the trackpad that can reset the SMC when it is low.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v. The trackpad having corrosion from liquid damage is a very common cause of no light on the magsafe charger & the system not turning on, when the trackpad or trackpad cable is corroded and holding this line down. .
definitions.SM_RESET_L: What is SM_RESET_L? This is a typo of SMC_RESET_L When you see SM_RESET_L, assume they meant to type SMC_RESET_L.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.AVREF_SMC: What is AVREF_SMC? AVREF_SMC is a reference voltage provided to the SMC so that its sensors have a reference to work from, this should be 3.3v.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  (SMC Reset "Button", Supervisor & AVREF Supply) rabbit hole from hell.
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  (SMC Reset "Button", Supervisor & AVREF Supply) rabbit hole from hell.

This post will show you just how little I know on these boards.  

I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> will not get "Green Light"
H20 damage around the SMC area.   I cleaned it, picked at it and reflowed any resistor that looks suspicious.   Even took them off to make sure.  I checked all their resistances and voltages and compared to a working board.  Still no green light. So I am jumping to SMC right...  Must be crud under it.    I did everything possible to not mess with that chip!   They eat time.  So I took it off and it was perfect.  No corrosion nothing.  Everything was clean.  Lucky for me I took it off I dragged it across a row of balls so I get to reball now.  

SMC is done.  looking around and measuring I notice that the <SIGNAL>SM_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is staying low.  I am thinking why didn't I drop to brain mode sooner.   After a few minutes of looking I get tangled around this (circuit SMC Reset "Button", Supervisor & AVREF Supply) and think it has to be something in the area.  This is the only area that needed slight rework when I first started in on this board.   There was a pad eaten away on <RESISTOR>R5000</RESISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C5020</CAPACITOR>.  The power inputs of course.  where else would water damage be.. I notice that <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> is 0.0V  I check chip power, The <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SMC</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_SMCVREF</SIGNAL> are both present.  Missing is the <SIGNAL>SMC_TPAD_RST_L</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> both reading low.   I decided to change the chip.  U 5110 was repealed and replaced. I noticed that with the chip off the unit would green light and do a S0 bounce!  I dropped on the replacement <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> sure I had it figured out and I am the man only to discover same problem.    I was looking down a rabbit hole. 

Please put me on the path of righteousness and help me find my way.   I am in a rabbit hole and stuck.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  (SMC Reset "Button", Supervisor & AVREF Supply) rabbit hole from hell.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  (SMC Reset "Button", Supervisor & AVREF Supply) rabbit hole from hell.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  (SMC Reset "Button", Supervisor & AVREF Supply) rabbit hole from hell.
threads.message:
As you miss both pins 5 & 8 voltage, is a problem with <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>.
Probably bad traces/pads, or bad solders.
If got SMC reaction without <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>, means no short on <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>, or other issue with that signal.
However, check diode mode to ground on pin8.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  (SMC Reset "Button", Supervisor & AVREF Supply) rabbit hole from hell.
threads.message:
<CHIP>U5110</CHIP>

pin 8 is 0.540 VDC drop Compared to tester and it was similar.
I actually went around all the legs and compared with a known good tester and all were similar 1-8

After I replaced this IC <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> I ended back at it. So I replaced it again. I have a habit of putting known good parts back on donor boards if the swap did not work. So.. I grabbed a third board and replaced it a third time just to make sure.

I am awfully tempted to run a jumper and force it high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  (SMC Reset "Button", Supervisor & AVREF Supply) rabbit hole from hell.
threads.message:
Forcing <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is not a good idea.
Reset signal must be disabled after power rails get stable.
If not board will start randomly, not always working good.
Be sure <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> is good too.
So needs a delay, generated by <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>; it also generates <SIGNAL>AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  (SMC Reset "Button", Supervisor & AVREF Supply) rabbit hole from hell.
threads.message:
This problem is definitely not the chip.  I can't find LB damage.   I think this is a rabbit hole of some kind.   
I am going to recommend LB replacement on this one and throw the board in the "Toy Box" for future torture.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  (SMC Reset "Button", Supervisor & AVREF Supply) rabbit hole from hell.
threads.message:
Remove <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR> and see if <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> goes high.
If yes, change <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.
If not, change SMC.
Do you get stable 3V at <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> removing <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>?
